Fields.DialogueText: I hate the down time between battles.
You should enjoy the time to relax.
Time away from battle makes us soft!
The only way to grow stronger is to continue fighting!

Fields.MenuText: Agreed, but rest is important.
Think of it as a chance to spend more time together.
I'm not so eager for our next fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. But too much rest creates laziness.
To be honest, I feel closest to you in the heat of battle.
You will be once the boredom sets in.
*ALARM*
Finally! The enemy.
Just wait - you're going to miss the peace and quiet.
Let's see if your "down time" has had any benefit.
@BATTLE
No, I'm kidding.
They're back for more! Battlestations!
@BATTLE
Not our finest performance, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: A victory is a victory.
How would you have done better?
We'll fight harder next time, then.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not consider survival the same as victory.
We should be training harder!
More battles like that and there won't be a next time!
Perhaps the crew could use more training...
The more you sweat in training, the less you bleed in battle.

Fields.MenuText: I could order more training drills? It couldn't hurt.
Do you think the crew can handle it?
We have to be careful about overworking ourselves.

Fields.DialogueText: It WILL hurt. But in the BEST way.
If they are warriors they will rise to the challenge.
Nonsense! We must train.
And I suppose you'd like to lead the training.
Of course!
How is the training coming along?

Fields.MenuText: Impressive. You're a great trainer.
We couldn't have done it without you.
Your warrior ethic is rubbing off on the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. I am doing my best.
It means a lot to hear you say that.
I'm merely helping them realize their potential.
There is one thing that concerns me.
The Morganas?
Yes. They are an unpredictable foe.
There are some things you cannot train for.
Hope for the best, prepare for the worst.
Is that another old saying, Captain?
Not as old as any of yours, I'd imagine.
... I like it.
@BATTLE
Excellent, captain. We are seeing improvements in rate of fire, response times, and accuracy.
A new song?
Yes. A battle hymn!
It will motivate the crew in battle.
The right music can calm the nerves...
Or strengthen the spirit!
I'm searching for the right tune.

Fields.MenuText: Whatever you decide, I'm sure it will be beautiful.
It's good to see you being confident about your music.
Do you really think music is going to help?

Fields.DialogueText: ... Thank you. I'll try my best.
I have you to thank for that.
Music has a storied history on the battlefield.
*ALARM*
An attack! But I haven't finished my song!
I suppose you'll have to improvise.
At least I'll have some vigorous inspiration!
@BATTLE
Captain, listen to this!
What is it?
The Battle Hymn of Cossack!
Do you like it?

Fields.MenuText: It could use some work.
It suits you very well.
Lovely. Just like you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! It is a first rendition.
I think it could still be better.
Stop! I do not like to blush, Captain.
I should make another song to strike fear into the Morganas!
I'm not sure the Morganas feel anything, let alone fear.
Then it should be our job to fix that.
@BATTLE
*VIGOROUS WAR MUSIC*
They're back for more! Battlestations!
@BATTLE
Cossack, we have a new mission.
Finally! A chance to put our training to the test.
We're being ordered to escort a convoy.
I'm bored already...

Fields.MenuText: You didn't let me finish.
Not challenging enough for you?
Too bad, orders are orders.

Fields.DialogueText: There's more?
Our skills would be better utilized on the front line.
It doesn't make those orders any less boring.
The convoy is slated to join a major offensive against the Morganas in the North Sea.
Ah! Now you have my attention.
I had a feeling.
Well, what are we waiting for? Let's get to that convoy!
So far, this has been too easy.

Fields.MenuText: I agree. We could use more of a challenge.
Maybe your training has paid off too well?
The mission has only just begun.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps the Morganas are trying to trick us.
Perhaps. I do make an excellent instructor.
Beginnings are not always easy.
We can't allow ourselves to feel a false sense of security.
Agreed.
*ALARM*
Where are... there! See them?
We have to keep them away from the convoy!
With my training we won't suffer a single casualty, Captain.
@BATTLE
Status report?
We're fit to keep fighting, Captain.
And the convoy?
Several of the ships were heavily damaged.
It will take at least a day to make repairs.
Meanwhile, we'll be stuck here.
Da.

Fields.MenuText: We should have done a better job protecting them.
We should radio for support.
We may be in over our heads with this mission.

Fields.DialogueText: We must learn from our failures, Captain.
They will never arrive before the enemy.
We only get stronger through tougher challenges.
*ALARM*
We have to stand our ground and protect the convoy!
@BATTLE
Still working on your song?
It's nearly complete.

Fields.MenuText: I think it'll be a great morale boost.
Stop wasting time. We need to be planning for battle.
Your songs have brought us good luck so far.

Fields.DialogueText: I want to inspire our crew to be true warriors!
... I'm sorry you think it is silly, Captain.
Yes. Luck will always be on our side.
Listen to this...
*INSPIRED SONG DRAFT*
*ALARM*
I'm not a fan of the last few notes.
Ha! But the alarm does have an exciting ring to it!
I hope your song is complete enough to bring us luck this time.
There is nothing like a deadline to inspire creativity...
@BATTLE
They're back for more! Battlestations!
@BATTLE
I must admit, I am enjoying this.
Playing music? Or fighting?
Having the enemy come to us. It is... convenient.
As long as we keep winning.
All this sitting still bothers me, however.
Are the attacks making you uneasy?
Of course not! But this lack of travel makes me anxious.
Then you'll be happy to know the convoy repairs are complete.
Finally. I was beginning to think I'd have to compose a song to make them work faster.

Fields.MenuText: Haha. Maybe being a musician suits you more than a warrior.
I'd happily listen to any song you made.
Nothing's ever good enough for you, is it?

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt that... but perhaps when the war is over...
Careful, Captain. I may challenge you on that.
If I am hard on anyone, it is only because I care.
We're nearly at the rendezvous point.
*ALARM*
There's an enemy blockade in our path, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: We'll have to push through it!
Careful, we can't risk the convoy.
Maybe we can outmanouevre them.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes! We'll crush them!
The best protection will be a strong offence, Captain.
I'd prefer a direct attack.
We'll find their weakest point and cut through it.
I have to take back what I said before.
About what?
Taking the enemy head-on is still much more enjoyable than waiting for them!
@BATTLE
We have a head start, at least.
Yes, but one of the convoy ships is damaged.
We're receiving an SOS, Captain. They're sinking!

Fields.MenuText: I trust you won't object if we end up with a few extra passengers?
We have to rescue them!
Damn. The timing could've been better.

Fields.DialogueText: Try not to make it thirteen.
The best way to save them will be to destroy the enemy.
Maybe so - but our duty is clear.
*ALARM*
Turn the ship around! We're going to save them!
Do you have a plan?

Fields.MenuText: Now's the time for action, not planning.
Let's defeat the enemy first.
I just want to get the convoy crew to safety.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain. ONWARD INTO BATTLE!
My favorite strategy!
We'll save them, Captain. And we will CRUSH the enemy in the process!
@BATTLE
The convoy ship is heavily damaged, Captain.
Get closer! We'll have to bring the crew on board.
What about the ship's supplies?

Fields.MenuText: The safety of the crew comes first.
We can accept the loss.
Better that no one gets the supplies than the enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Our OWN safety should come first.
I will trust your judgment, Captain.
That is true...
I've just thought of something, Captain.
A new plan?
No... what if the convoy ship has...
A CAT on board?!
Not this again.
No! I can tolerate one, but NO MORE CATS!
Can we at least rescue the sailors first?
Of course, but if they have a cat I'm leaving it to die.
@BATTLE
They're back for more! Battlestations!
@BATTLE
We managed to save the crew and some of the supplies.
And best of all, no cat!

Fields.MenuText: You can't still believe cats are bad luck after all we've been through.
You'll be happy to know we also have more than thirteen survivors aboard now.
Admit it. You were hoping there was a cat!

Fields.DialogueText: How do you know cats aren't the reason we've been through so much?!
Do we need to throw the cat overboard to make room for them?
The one cat we have aboard is one too many!
*MEOW*
Speak of the devil!
That feline IS the devil, Captain.
By the way, I've been meaning to ask...
I've noticed the cat has a new collar.
So?
So... It's blue. Blue is your favorite color, right?
What are you implying, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: It was just a question.
Nothing. Nothing at all.
Oh, I think you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. A silly question.
Good.
I promise you I do not.
No doubt one of the crew is playing a prank on me.
Haha. Whatever you say, Cossack.
Vot oni idut! Battlestations!
@BATTLE
Captain, may I have a word?
Of course! What's on your mind?
I've been having some troubling thoughts.
About the war?
About after the war... I never asked you...
What will you do when the fighting has ended, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I haven't given it much thought.
I'd like to do something peaceful.
Hopefully I can settle down with someone special.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand. It's hard to focus on anything outside of the war.
That sounds nice. Maybe with lots of traveling?
Do you... have someone in mind?
Where is all of this coming from, Cossack?
... I'm not sure.
Captain, do you remember when you gave me the bouquet of sunflowers?
Podsolnukhi?
Ha! Indeed!
... Why did you give them to me?

Fields.MenuText: Why do you think?
I wanted to give you something special.
Because I care about you.

Fields.DialogueText: I think that I know, but I want to be sure.
Do you think I'm special?
No one has ever done anything like that for me before.
I'm not sure how I'm supposed to feel.

Fields.MenuText: Just be honest with yourself.
Well, I'm sure about how I feel about you.
I can't tell you how you should feel.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm trying. But I think I may be... afraid.
And how do you feel?
I know. This is just very new to me.
I think you know how I feel...
Captain...
DAMMIT!
... Not what I was expecting, but-
*ALARM*
Ah.
@BATTLE
Another new song?
Yes, this one is special.
A special battle hymn?
Not everything is about battle.
That's the first time I'm hearing that from you.
Have we received new orders yet?
Yes. It's a seek and destroy. Your favorite.
EXCELLENT! Who is the target?
We're hunting Morgana ships that have been targeting our convoys.
This mission keeps getting better!

Fields.MenuText: Your new song is coming just in time.
Are you up for the challenge?
Make sure you send a prayer for our good luck.

Fields.DialogueText: I... suppose it is.
Always! But are you?
It is the Morganas who should be praying...
@BATTLE
Captain...
@BATTLE
Captain, I believe I have a way of tracking the Morganas.
I'm all ears.
Remember when we escorted the convoy? The enemy came to us.
Yes, and you hated the waiting.
I did! But it gave me an idea...
What if we created a decoy convoy?
You mean create a fake convoy to lure the Morganas to us?
Exactly. We'll let them attack the decoys, then steal the advantage with a surprise attack.

Fields.MenuText: It's crazy, but certainly not without precedent.
Even if we can drum up some old hulks, command won't like us wasting resources.
And what if the Morganas see through our ruse?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not crazy. It's clever... and ruthless!
Call them acceptable losses for a decisive victory.
They will not, trust me.
It will be up to Command, but I support this plan - and I'll ask around to see if we can find ourselves some boats ready to scrap.
Thank you, Captain. That means a lot to me.

Fields.MenuText: I'd trust you with my life.
I'll always believe in you.
It's much better than your usual plans.

Fields.DialogueText: ... The feeling is mutual, Captain.
Your faith only strengthens my resolve, Captain.
Someone once told me a direct attack is not always the best option.
I see them.
Oh, I love it when they come to us!
@BATTLE
Good news - Command is allowing us several junk ships to use for the fake convoy.
I won't let them down!
Once we've crushed the Morganas, they'll see the wisdom in our plan.
Our plan? It was all your idea.
I consider it a team effort.

Fields.MenuText: You should take credit where it's due.
Since when are we a team?
We'll also share the blame if we fail.

Fields.DialogueText: I would not have thought of it without your advice, Captain.
We've always been a team, have we not?
All the more reason to succeed, then.
The decoys will be here in a few days. We must take the time to prepare.
We will be more than prepared... we will be poised for victory!
... More waiting. How much longer will it take?
You knew this was part of the plan.
Perhaps I gave the Morganas too much credit. Maybe they will never find us...

Fields.MenuText: They'll find us soon, I have a feeling.
This plan is a complete wash so far.
Good things come to those who wait.

Fields.DialogueText: What makes you so certain?
Yes, but it could still pay off.
Better things come to those who work hard.
... CAPTAIN! I've spotted them. We have Morganas incoming on the horizon.
Don't engage until they attack the convoy.
We have to let them think they've surprised us.
They've drawn close enough. Waiting time is over. ATTACK!
Cossack, wait!
@BATTLE
We engaged the Morganas too soon!
Yes, but we achieved victory.

Fields.MenuText: That's beside the point - you disobeyed orders!
You could have gotten us all killed.
... I suppose I can't argue with the results.

Fields.DialogueText: We were assured victory regardless.
I knew we would prevail.
No. No you cannot.
But don't do it again.
When the shooting starts, you and I have to be on the same page, no matter how stupid you might think I'm being. It's the only way all of this can work.
What does it matter? All we have is this war.
What do you mean?
After the war, there is nothing! It makes no difference.

Fields.MenuText: It makes plenty of difference to me!
Where is this coming from?
After the war we have our REAL lives.

Fields.DialogueText: But why should it?
Because I have NOTHING without this war!
No. YOU do. I have nothing.
After this war, you'll forget all about me.
@BATTLE
Cossack, you have to talk to me.
I have nothing more to say.

Fields.MenuText: So I should let it go, then?
I have plenty to say.
Fine. Just forget it.

Fields.DialogueText: We have a mission to think about.
I do not care to hear what you have to say!
I'm doing my best to.
Then I guess I'll leave you alone...
NO! Captain, wait...
Yes?
I'm sorry. The stress of battle is getting to me.

Fields.MenuText: This isn't about the Morganas. It's about you and me.
I can understand that.
Nothing excuses your behavior lately.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I know.
I truly apologize, Captain.
Do you... hate me, now?
*ALARM*
Another wave of Morganas!
@BATTLE
Why the sad melody, Cossack? We won today.

Fields.MenuText: It's okay, you can tell me.
Fine, I'll leave it alone.
Have I done something wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: It's just...
I'm sorry. I have just been wondering...
No, it's nothing like that.
Captain, what will happen to us?
What do you mean?
After the war. What will happen?

Fields.MenuText: I can't predict the future.
What do you mean? We'll always be together.
It does no good worrying about that sort of thing.

Fields.DialogueText: No. I know.
Do you mean that? Really?
I know, but I cannot help it.
At the end of the day I'm... what I am. And you're a human.
I haven't forgotten that.
Then how do you plan for us to be together after the fighting ends?
When the war is over you'll have to leave the ship... and me.
... Cossack.
It's nothing.
Captain, will you listen to this melody?
Sure, Cossack.
... How does it make you feel?

Fields.MenuText: Rather slow for a battle hymn, don't you think?
It's beautiful. What's it called?
I love it.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a love song, not a battle hymn.
It doesn't have a name just yet.
I'm very happy to hear that.
I have been thinking of you a lot lately, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Good thoughts, I hope?
I've been thinking about you too.
Don't get soft on me, Cossack.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing but good thoughts.
Thinking of you makes me... happy.
Me? Soft? Never!
This song. I wrote it for you.
For me? Why?
*ALARM*
More Morganas approaching!
@BATTLE
Here they come!
@BATTLE
Your plan played out excellently, Cossack.

Fields.MenuText: Keep this up and we'll win this war soon.
We make a formidable team.
Your training and hard work has really paid off.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes! Glorious victory is within our grasp.
The BEST team!
I'm doing my best to help us all.
... Captain?
Yes, Cossack?
Did you think more about my question? About after the war?
I have.
And?

Fields.MenuText: Let's make the most of the time we have now.
I don't know how, but if we're meant to be together, we'll find a way.
I don't have an answer, but I know how I feel.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. I would like that.
If you believe that, then I must as well.
I feel the same way.
... What's with that look?
Tell me how you feel. About me.

Fields.MenuText: Ya lyublyu tebya (I love you).
I love you.
You first. Unless the great warrior is afraid of showing her feelings.

Fields.DialogueText: Ya tozhe tebya lyublyu (I love you too.)
I love you too. Haha, but next time I'd like to hear it in Russian.
I will accept any challenge... I'll say it... I love you, Captain.
I am more cunning than any Morgana.
